section.title: Expressing ability
section.sectiontitle: Use can to talk about present or 'general' ability.
section.sectiontitle2: Use will be able to to talk about future ability.
section.text3a: She'll be able to run 100 metres in under 11 seconds by the end of the year.
section.text4a: I'll be able to set up my own business when I've finished the course.

section.title: Expressing ability
section.sectiontitle: Use could or was / were able to to talk about past or 'general' ability.
section.text1a: They could both ski quite well by the time they were seven or eight years old.
section.text2a: She was able to communicate effectively in Arabic after working in Egypt for a year.
section.sectiontitle2: Use was / were able to or managed to or succeeded in (+ -ing) to say what someone could do on a particular occasion.
section.text3a: They were able to get into the house by forcing open the back door.
section.text4a: We succeeded in cleaning up the whole house before my parents got back.

section.title: Expressing ability
section.sectiontitle: Use know how to and great at, good at, bad at and hopeless at to describe different levels of ability.
section.text1a: She knows how to count to ten in Japanese.
section.text2a: I'm hopeless at cooking. I usually get a take-away on the way home from work.
